newsitem.title: UK: LME copper slips back below $1,970, pares gains.
newsitem.headline: LME copper slips back below $1,970, pares gains.

text.p: Copper prices turned tail above $1,970 during late afternoon LME trading on Thursday, with profit-taking and technical selling persuading speculative buyers to hold their fire, traders said.
Nevertheless the market still concluded a fairly active session in the plus column, and is in good shape for another attempt on the $1,970 level and above in coming days.
"All the ingredients are in place - stocks should be down, the spreads are tight, and there is option covering on time decay to be done," one said.

Warehouse stock data will be of paramount importance on Friday, with the general expectation being a decline of some 5,000/10,000 tonnes. However, the current impressive run of drawdowns may be nearing an end, as some of the metal shipped from Europe is expected to land in Singapore soon.

"The jury is still out on whether the (stock) falls are consumption or just relocation. It could be some time before we find out, because the Chinese figures (import/export) will not show for a month or so," another trader said.
If copper is destined for consumption it will be custom-cleared. If it is being moved into bonded warehouses it may well be sold back on to the world market.
Final three months business on the kerb was at $1,958, an $8 a tonne advance from Wednesday's closing kerb.
Elsewhere, zinc prices relinquished highs near $1,070 resistance, with the market in need of a breather after a run-up towards five-month highs.
But the short-term outlook remains bright, given current fund interest, notably the perception that international financier George Soros has a market presence now.
Also, there are expectations of a fall in warehouse stocks on Friday, as well as some late-January 1997 tightness. Final trade was at $1,066, up $12 from the overnight close.

Aluminium stumbled at the $1,450 hurdle in mid-afternoon, having earlier ridden higher in copper's slipstream through the $1,440 level. In the short term traders still favour a foray towards $1,500, but movements will be choppy.
Last trade today was at $1,437, still up $9 from yesterday's kerb. A stock drawdown is expected tomorrow, they said.
Nickel struggled to make much headway throughout the session and mostly held close to overnight levels. Final kerb business was at $7,330, against Wednesday's close of $7,340.
Lead's upside flurry petered out during the afternoon, with prices drifting back from the highs to close at $752, still up $4 from yesterday and a technically sound finish.
The tin market had occasional liaisons with the $6,000 level, but was content to remain in a narrow range. Last trade was at $5,985, little different from the overnight $5,990.
Alloy traded intermittently today, but was generally steadier, and three months finished at $1,288/90, up from Wednesday's close of $1,285.
